de.esoco.lib.proxy.interception

Class MethodInterception

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.esoco.lib.proxy.interception.MethodInterception
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Interception

    public abstract class MethodInterception
extends java.lang.Object
implements Interception
    An abstract Interception implementation that maps intercepted methods to equally named methods in a subclass. The default implementation of the invoke() method uses reflection to dispatch method calls to subclass methods. Therefore subclasses need to implement the intercepted methods with the same name and parameter list, plus two additional parameters as the first and second argument. These parameters will be the invoked proxy object and the target object, respectively.

    Attention: because of restrictions in the use of reflection the invoked subclass and the methods to be invoked must be publicly accessible, else an IllegalAccessException will be thrown. This means especially that is not possible to create anonymous inner classes (which are implicitly private) as subclasses of MethodInterception which use the dispatch mechanism.

    The existence of matching methods in the subclass will be checked in the constructor or when additional methods are added through the corresponding methods. In general it is recommended to use these methods only during instance initialisation (i.e. from the subclass constructors). If no matching method can be found an IllegalArgumentException will be thrown. That means that the validity of an interception mapping will be verified as soon as an instance of the subclass is created. If instances are not always created automatically by an application the developer should make sure that an interception implementation is instatiated at least during testing (e.g. in a unit test).

    The two additional parameters of the subclass interception methods may be of any type but must represent the concrete type (or one of it's supertypes) that will be used at runtime. That means that there is a risk of runtime errors when a type mismatch occurs. If in doubt a developer should use the class Object (or another generic supertype) as the argument type for both parameters. Alternatively an implementation may choose to override the method convertArgTypes(Method) to change the argument mapping for some or all methods.

    If a subclass wants to modify the parameter list or other aspects of all or certain method calls it can override the invoke() method to implement the necessary conversions. If an implementation needs to change the mapping of methods it can do so by overriding the addMethod(Method) method.

    • Constructor Detail

      • MethodInterception

        public MethodInterception(java.lang.reflect.Method... rMethods)
        Creates a new instance that intercepts one or more methods. If no methods are provided the subclass implementation can set the intercepted methods by invoking one of the methods addMethod(Method) or addMethods(Collection, boolean).

        An assertion will be thrown at development time if the variable parameter list is empty or NULL.

        Parameters:
        rMethods - The methods to intercept
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If no matching method for an argument exception exists in this class

      • MethodInterception

        public MethodInterception(java.lang.Class<?> rClass)
        Creates a new instance that intercepts all public methods declared by a particular class. This does not include methods declared by any superclass of the argument class. Subclasses can add additional public methods from other classes by means of one of the addMethod() methods.
        Parameters:
        rClass - The class to intercept the public methods of
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If for a certain intercepted method no matching method exists in this class

      • MethodInterception

        public MethodInterception(java.lang.Class<?> rClass,
                          java.lang.String... rMethods)
        Creates a new instance that intercepts certain methods declared by a particular class. For each method name all methods will that name will be intercepted. That means, if the intercepted class has overloaded methods with distinct parameter lists the subclass must implement corresponding methods for each variant. Else an IllegalArgumentException will be thrown.

        This constructor will check the existence of the corresponding methods in the intercepted class as well as in this (sub)class. In the latter case two additional parameters are expected (for details see the class documentation).

        Parameters:
        rClass - The class to intercept the public methods of
        rMethods - The names of the intercepted methods
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If for one of the given method names either no intercepted method exists in the given class or no matching method(s) exists in this class

    • Method Detail

      • invoke

        public java.lang.Object invoke(java.lang.Object rProxy,
                               java.lang.reflect.Method rOriginalMethod,
                               java.lang.Object rTarget,
                               java.lang.Object[] rArgs)
                        throws java.lang.Throwable
        Overridden to dispatch the invocation to an equal-named method in this interception instance, but with two additional first arguments which contain a reference to the EWT proxy and the implementation target object, respectively.
        Specified by:
        invoke in interface Interception
        Parameters:
        rProxy - The proxy on which the method has been invoked
        rOriginalMethod - The original method that has been invoked
        rTarget - The object on which the method shall be invoked
        rArgs - The original method arguments
        Returns:
        The result of the method call or of the interception
        Throws:
        java.lang.Throwable - Any kind of exception may be thrown
        See Also:
        Interception.invoke(Object, Method, Object, Object[])

      • addMethod

        protected void addMethod(java.lang.reflect.Method rMethod)
        Adds a method mapping by searching for a public method in this class that matches the argument method. The target method must have the same name and parameter lisdt.
        Parameters:
        rMethod - The name of the public method to add
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If no target method with the given name exists

      • addMethod

        protected void addMethod(java.lang.Class<?> rClass,
                         java.lang.String sMethod)
        Adds all public methods with a certain name to this interception. If the intercepted class has overloaded methods with distinct parameter lists the subclass must implement corresponding methods for each variant. Else an IllegalArgumentException will be thrown.
        Parameters:
        rClass - The class to intercept the public methods of
        sMethod - The name of the intercepted method(s)

      • addMethods

        protected void addMethods(java.lang.Class<?> rClass)
        Adds all public methods declared by a particular class. This does not include methods declared by any superclass of the argument class. These classes must be added separately if necessary.
        Parameters:
        rClass - The class to add the public methods of

      • addMethods

        protected void addMethods(java.util.Collection<java.lang.reflect.Method> rMethods,
                          boolean bPublicOnly)
        Adds all methods from an array to this interception.
        Parameters:
        rMethods - The array of methods to add
        bPublicOnly - If TRUE, only public methods will be added; else any method in the array will be added

      • convertArgTypes

        protected java.lang.Class<?>[] convertArgTypes(java.lang.reflect.Method rMethod)
        Converts the list of argument types of a method for the lookup of the corresponding subclass method. The default implementation adds two additional first parameters for the proxy and the target object, respectively.
        Parameters:
        rMethod - The method to convert the argument types of
        Returns:
        A class array containing the converted type list

      • mapMethod

        protected java.lang.reflect.Method mapMethod(java.lang.reflect.Method rMethod)
        Maps a source method to a target method in this class that has two additional parameters. May be overridden by subclasses to implement different mappings. Invoked from addMethod(Method).
        Parameters:
        rMethod - The source method to map
        Returns:
        The mapped target method or NULL if no matching method could be found
